item.title: Terraform Opinion #23: Use list of objects over map of maps
item.description: Lately, I’ve seen quite a bit of Terraform snippets that use a static map of maps to directly configure resources. For example: locals { map_of_maps = { name1 = { attribute1 = "name1-value1" attribute2 = "name1-value2" attribute3 = "name1-value3" } name2 = { attribute1 = "name2-value1" attribute2 = "name2-value2" attribute3 = "name2-value3" } name3 = { attribute1 = "name3-value1" attribute2 = "name3-value2" attribute3 = "name3-value3" } } } resource "some_resource" "this" { for_each = local.

item.title: Tiered Subnet Calculator in Terraform
item.description: Update May 23th 2023: Things have changed since TF v0.13 like the resulting order (lexical sorting) of a set of objects with for. variable "tiers" { type = set(object({ name = string acl = string newbit = number })) } Using a list of objects will keep it’s current order so I can use the var.base_cidr_block as a starting point for generating network subnets for AWS. variable "tiers" { type = list(object({ name = string acl = string newbit = number })) } Updated the article with newer outputs from Terraform v1.
